name: Number of 3-dimensional polyominoes (or polycubes) with n cells.
comment: Here two polycubes that differ by reflection are considered different. - _Joerg Arndt_, Apr 26 2023
Number of oriented polyominoes with n cubical cells of the regular tiling with Schläfli symbol {4,3,4}.  For oriented polyominoes, chiral pairs are counted as two. - _Robert A. Russell_, Mar 21 2024
reference: J. R. Long and R. H. Holm, Enumeration and structural classification of clusters derived from parent solids ..., J. Amer. Chem. Soc., 116 (1984), 9987-10002.
W. F. Lunnon, Symmetry of cubical and general polyominoes, pp. 101-108 of R. C. Read, editor, Graph Theory and Computing. Academic Press, NY, 1972.
N. J. A. Sloane, A Handbook of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1973 (includes this sequence).
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
link: Nina Bohlmann and Ralf Benölken, Complex Tasks: Potentials and Pitfalls, Mathematics (2020) Vol. 8, No. 10, 1780.
C. J. Bouwkamp & N. J. A. Sloane, Correspondence, 1971.
Stanley Dodds, C# program for this sequence.
David A. Klarner, Some results concerning polyominoes, Fibonacci Quarterly 3 (1965), 9-20.
John Mason, Coordinate sets of examples of polycube symmetry
Phillip Thompson, Rust port of Stanley Dodds's algorithm.
example: Table showing total number and numbers with each group order.
The last 7 columns form sequences A066453, A066454, A066273, A066281, A066283, A066287, A066288.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_ and _J. H. Conway_
ext: The old value for a(11), 2522572, was corrected by _Achim Flammenkamp_ to 2522522, Feb 15 1999.
a(21)-a(22) (using Dodds's algorithm) from _Phillip Thompson_, Feb 07 2024
